docTitle.titlePart:
Promoting Dendritic Cell Migration by Airway
Epithelial Cells through Interleukin-17A-Induced
CCL20 Expression

byline.docAuthor: Li Yi n Hung, Fei Hua ng, Ti f f a ny T. Nguy en a nd Reen W u

front.div:
ABST R ACT
We previously demonstrated that IL-17A is a potent inducer of both human
Î²-defensin (hBD) 2 and CCL20/macrophage inflammatory protein (MIP)-3
expression in well-differentiated primary human airway epithelial cell (AEC)
cultures. In addition to having a common anti-microbial activity, both hBD2 and
CCL20 are principal chemotactic ligands specific to CCR6-positive dendritic
cells (DC) and T lymphocytes. To further explore the chemotactic significance of
IL-17A in the mouse model, we conducted studies using isolated primary mouse
AECs and Cc10-Il17 transgenic animals. Consistent with human AECs,
well-differentiated mouse AECs also expressed elevated mCcl20 when treated
with mIL-17A. This induction was time-and dose-dependent on the IL-17A
treatment, and the induction was inhibited by isohelenin, a specific inhibitor of
NF-B activation. Chemotactic assays showed that conditioned media from
mIL-17A-treated mouse AEC cultures stimulated the migration of CCR6-positive
mouse bone marrow-derived dendritic cells (BMDC) in vitro; this chemotactic
activity was blocked by anti-CCL20 neutralizing antibody. We found a
persistent elevation of mCcl20 message and the presence of CCR6-positive DCs
in bronchoalveolar lavage fluids, accompanied by increased mucin production in
the lungs of Cc10-Il17 transgenic mice, which overexpress IL-17A specifically in
the airway. Blocking the migration of CCR6 expressing cells in vivo lowered
mucin production in the airway. These results suggest a functional role of
IL-17A/CCL20 in regulating CCR6-positive DC migration and mucous cell
metaplasia.
front.note:
This research was supported in part by grants from NIH (HL077902, HL077315,
and ES00628)
